Honestly not much. Few parents trust kids with much money and learning about something without practicing it interests very few people. I teach financial literacy in high school and can tell you few students are ready to absorb and put into effective use even practical lessons prior to the last year or so of school. Sadly I am scheduled to teach this to freshmen (14 year olds), with a few students from other grades tossed in. The few older students do well enough, but the younger students do not see the vital difference between financial knowledge and other subjects: you might use geometry or algebra in your future life, but you will, guaranteed, use credit cards, loans, insurance, and other financial implements. Knowing how to do so wisely and how to wring the most benefits from each is worth every kid’s time and efforts, but few get this. Kids see school as what they have to do, it’s just what they have to put up with to socialize with their friends. The idea students approach financial literacy with more attention because adults see it as vital is sadly mistaken. Believe me, I wish this were not so, because financial literacy is vital as an adult.
